newsitem.title: FRANCE: Jospin reaffirms French left govt would back euro.
newsitem.headline: Jospin reaffirms French left govt would back euro.

text.p: French Socialist party leader Lionel Jospin said in a Thursday newspaper interview, ahead of Sunday's runoff election, that his party backed Europe's planned single currency and this would be the position of a left-wing government.

"We are for the single currency, since the outset. One can be against the single currency and that's a respectable stance but it would not be the position of a government," Jospin told afternoon daily newspaper Le Monde.

He was replying to a question about differences of position on the left, which took a lead in a first round vote in France's parliamentary election last Sunday. The smaller Communist party opposes the European monetary union plan and wants a referendum on the euro.

Jospin, whose rhetoric is being closely watched by markets for signals on the power balance on the left and how pragmatist a leftish government would be, also said his party's call for a shorter 35-hour work week to promote employment would not be something that happened immediately.

"On the 35-hour week, it's not 35 hours right away. We have to be clear on this. We have a three-year schedule, starting with a framework law, and then the opening of negotiations between the social partners," he said.
"The traditional caricatures of a Socialist-Communist coalition are not longer valid, we're not longer in the same period of history," Jospin said.

Asked if he feared a mobilisation of the right-wing vote in the second round after the left's first round lead, Jospin said: "I'm not counting out anything. This is a two-round poll. I do not think the dynamic should reverse but nothing's wrapped up".

Jospin also took a stab at the latest electoral manoeuvres on the right after the joint campaign-trail appearance of the socially-minded Philippe Seguin and free-marketeer Alain Madelin days ahead of the decisive second round vote.

While Seguin is widely seen as a more populist and socially minded player than outgoing prime minister Alain Juppe, Madelin is seen as one of the most ardent economic liberals on the French centre-right and was ousted by Juppe from the job of finance minister in 1995 after his firebrand style infuriated trade unions.
"This unlikely duo adds to the theatre of confusion and I think the French people will read it this way," Jospin said.
"They have not forgotten that he (Madelin) was removed from government within three months. They know that Mr Seguin is his opposite," he said.
